title: In setback to Turkey's Erdogan, opposition makes huge gains in local election
summary: Turkey's main opposition party on Sunday claimed victory in Istanbul and Ankara. President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, addressing supporters at his party's headquarters in the capital, acknowledged a 'turning point' and promised to respect the results.

title: Israelis stage largest anti-government protest since the war in Gaza began
summary: Stepping up pressure on Benjamin Netanyahu on Sunday, tens of thousands of Israelis urged the government to reach a cease-fire deal to free dozens of hostages and to hold early elections.

title: Anti-drone campaign intensifies as Olympic Games approach
summary: Thwarting potential drone intrusions, whether due to a terrorist attack or a media stunt by activists seeking to disrupt the event, has become a key concern for the organizers of this summer's Paris Olympic and Paralympic Games.

title: Why is Ukraine struggling to mobilize more troops?
summary: The wartorn country needs more troops to help its exhausted soldiers on the front line, but the issue is politically sensitive and has faced multiple setbacks.

title: After zero-Covid, China fears zero-tourist
summary: Sealed off during the health crisis, the Middle Kingdom is now opening its doors wide. Despite a visa waiver measure, the country is suffering from a tarnished image and struggling to attract Western visitors.

title: Beyoncé reclaims country
summary: 'Cowboy Carter', the American singer's eighth album released on Friday, sees her go back to country music's roots.

title: French police find remains of missing toddler in the Alps
summary: The bones of a 2-and-a-half-year-old, Emile, were found near the place where he was last seen in June, a French prosecutor announced.

title: Pope calls for end to wars in Gaza and Ukraine during Easter message
summary: Pope Francis was leading Easter ceremonies at the Vatican on Sunday.

title: IS rebuilds its networks in Syria, carrying out deadly ambushes
summary: According to UN experts, the organization still has 3,000 to 5,000 members in the Iraqi-Syrian zone, most notably in the Badiya desert, a steppe south of the Euphrates.

title: Canada's Foreign Interference Commission hears testimonies from diaspora
summary: A federal inquiry is investigating cases of foreign interference among the country's diaspora communities.

title: Romania and Bulgaria partially join EU Schengen travel zone
summary: The two countries joined the Schengen area's air and sea zones on Sunday after a 13-year wait.

title: In Germany, the Social Democratic Party is under attack for its weakness towards Moscow
summary: Criticized within his coalition, Chancellor Olaf Scholz is also accused by several historians of 'denying reality' concerning the threat posed by Russia.

title: Israel wants to 'expand' its campaign against Hezbollah
summary: Israeli strikes killed dozens of Syrian soldiers on Friday. Lebanon fears an escalation of the conflict.

title: Paris Olympics, elections: The threat of increased cyberattacks in 2024 is 'real'
summary: A chief analyst at Mandiant, a company specializing in tracking down and studying elite hacker groups, says major political and cultural events in 2024 represent opportunities for state-sponsored hackers to wreak havoc.

title: Poland, Czech Republic warn of Russian interference ahead of European elections
summary: A Moscow-backed network, 'Voice of Europe', was busted by Prague earlier this week. The site reportedly paid MEPs to spread pro-Russian propaganda.

title: Paris 2024: Risk of heatwave raises fears of a stifling Games
summary: While it's impossible to predict whether the Paris Olympic Games will coincide with a heatwave, the fact that the competition (July 26-August 11) takes place during the 'climatological peak' means that there's a real threat of a major hot spell.

title: Swedish feminist organizations oppose gender self-identification law
summary: A reform proposal aimed at simplifying procedures for changing sex on official documents has provoked opposition from feminist organizations in the country.

title: Sweden's universities hit with financial strain
summary: Distance learning, shorter courses, fewer places for PhD students: To keep up with rising costs, especially rent, Swedish universities are looking to limit their spending.

title: Instagram and the syndrome of children with emoji heads
summary: Even though they think they are protecting them, Internet users who publish photos of their children, even if they hide their faces, are still exposing their offspring argues Pauline Croquet in her column.

title: Ireland, Europe's most pro-Palestinian nation: 'We too have known oppression and famine'
summary: Irish mobilization in support of Palestine has taken on unprecedented proportions since October 7, solidarity that is rooted in a shared past of British occupation and armed struggle.

title: 'Europe must adapt and build a war economy without delay'
summary: Former French Junior Minister for Europe Laurence Boone and former Moldovan Foreign Minister Nicu Popescu argue in an op-ed for 'Le Monde' that the European Union must act quickly to adapt its economy and regulatory framework to the new geopolitical reality.

title: Walk more and faster: A simple way to do yourself good
summary: The French Athletics Federation is launching a program to evaluate walking speed. The aim is to raise the profile of this activity in the daily lives of French people.

title: In Jerusalem, tens of thousands of demonstrators demand Netanyahu's resignation
summary: The Israeli prime minister is accused of prolonging the war and stalling negotiations with Hamas over the release of the hostages in order to stay in power.

title: Germany becomes largest EU country to legalize cannabis for recreational use
summary: Under the first step in the much-debated new law, adults over 18 are now allowed to carry 25 grams of dried cannabis and cultivate up to three marijuana plants at home.

title: Turkey's local elections: Sweeping victory for the opposition is stinging defeat for Erdogan
summary: The Republican People's Party was the big winner in Sunday's vote. It gained ground in the major cities it already held, including Istanbul, Ankara and Izmir, and took strongholds from Erdogan's AKP in the Black Sea region and Anatolia.

title: Israeli army says it has pulled out of Al-Shifa Hospital, the largest in the Gaza Strip
summary: Israel had been sealing off the area around the hospital in Gaza City for two weeks, claiming to be fighting 'terrorists' there. Hamas claims to have discovered 'dozens' of corpses 'in and around the Al-Shifa medical complex' after its departure.

title: Germans celebrate legalization of recreational cannabis
summary: As of Monday, April 1, recreational cannabis consumption is now legal for adults in Germany.

title: Delhi chief minister moved to jail for two weeks
summary: Opposition parties say it is part of a crackdown by Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government ahead of national elections later this month.
